subject: Re: [junit] Help plz...
msgSnippet: On Tuesday 16 September 2003 11:22, Chan wrote: [yes, there are comments, but here s some of Chan s code first ...] ... Your suite, when it runs, runs
messageBody:
On Tuesday 16 September 2003 11:22, Chan wrote:

[yes, there are comments, but here's some of Chan's code first ...]

> /* Test Program TestLanguageVector.java*/
> /* This programs fails when i run a negative test. Plz go thro the comments
> i have typed */
>
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import java.util.*;
> import java.io.*;

> class TestLanguageVector extends TestCase {
> LanguageVector langvect =new LanguageVector();
> public void testlangvect(){
> System.out.println("value of langvect.length"+langvect.length);
> assertEquals(2,langvect.length);
> /* the assert fails when i give other value than 2, and the program throws
> exception and stops, the next assertion is not tested and no FALIURE mssg
> is given.*/
> assertEquals("COBOL",langvect.list.elementAt(2));
> }
>
> public static Test suite(){
> return new TestSuite("TestLanguageVector.class");
> }

Your suite, when it runs, runs testlangvect [better would be testLangVect],
which makes a new empty vector, assigns it into langvect, and then
asserts that its length is 2. Since its length will be 0, you'll get a failure
[ie an exception is raised and caught by the junit machinery]. Because
the assert failed, the COBOL test isn't executed. (And since the vector
is empty, the COBOL test certainly won't succeed.)

> public static void main(String args[])
> {
>
> String params[] = {"TOMCAT","EJB"};
> /*I passs parameters to the main () of LanguageVector.java */
> LanguageVector.main(params);

That call doesn't do anything useful with the test code. It fiddles around and
prints stuff out.

> /*1.If the below two stmts are not added the testlangvect() is not
> getting innitaited */
> /*2. If I run negative test the Faliure msg is not displayed
> the program stops after throwing the first Exception */
>
> TestLanguageVector testlangVector= new TestLanguageVector();
> testlangVector.testlangvect();

You're running the test outside the test framework, so assertion failures will
become exceptions. Don't do that. Run the test using the suite ...

> junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());

... as you do here. You need to decide what you actually want to test, and
write a test for it. What *do* you want to test? I can't tell from the code what
you're trying to achieve.

> System.out.println("Test Stmt");
> }
> }

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
